title: 106_s250
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Prosecutor Ethics Act" and establishes ethical standards for federal prosecutors. The "Federal Prosecutor Ethics Act" amends Title 28, United States Code to establish ethical standards for Federal prosecutors. It defines the ethical standards for Federal prosecutors and exempts them from State laws that conflict with Federal law or policy. The "Federal Prosecutor Ethics Act" amends Title 28, United States Code to establish ethical standards for Federal prosecutors directly engaged in prosecuting violations of Federal civil or criminal law. The "Federal Prosecutor Ethics Act" amends Title 28, United States Code to establish ethical standards for Federal prosecutors. The Attorney General must promulgate regulations within 90 days to enforce section 530B. Department of Justice employees are prohibited from seeking indictments without reasonable belief of probable cause. The United States Attorneys' Manual outlines ethical standards for Federal prosecutors, including obligations under Brady v. Maryland, prohibition of misleading courts, offering false evidence, altering evidence, influencing witness testimony, and violating a defendant's right to discovery. The United States Attorneys' Manual sets ethical standards for Federal prosecutors, including prohibitions against offering sexual activities to government witnesses, disseminating confidential information improperly, and violating a defendant's right to discovery. The Attorney General establishes penalties for prohibited conduct, including reprimand, demotion, dismissal, suspension, ethical charges referral, and grand jury referral for criminal prosecution. This does not establish substantive rights for defendants or litigants. The Attorney General can establish penalties for prohibited conduct, such as reprimand, demotion, dismissal, suspension, ethical charges referral, and grand jury referral for criminal prosecution. This does not establish substantive rights for defendants or litigants. The Attorney General is required to submit an annual report on the activities and operations of the Office of Professional to the Committees on the Judiciary and on Appropriations of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Office of Professional Responsibility at the Department of Justice submits an annual report to Congress detailing investigations, findings of misconduct or violations, and maintaining confidentiality. The Office of Professional Responsibility at the Department of Justice submits an annual report to Congress detailing investigations, findings of misconduct or violations, and maintaining confidentiality. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct is established to review specific Federal duties related to investigation and prosecution of violations of Federal law. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct is tasked with reviewing the regulation of Federal prosecutors' conduct by State laws, investigating and punishing inappropriate conduct, and submitting a report within 12 months of its members' appointment. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct, appointed under paragraph (2)(B), submits a report to the Attorney General with recommendations after reviewing matters. The Commission consults with various entities, including the Attorney General, Committees on the Judiciary, and legal organizations. The Commission's membership is composed of individuals specified in the regulations. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct consists of 7 members appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States, who must be judges. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct consists of 7 members appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States, who must be judges. The members of the Commission shall be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission will elect a chairperson and vice chairperson from its members. A quorum consists of four members, with two members able to conduct hearings. Members who are officers or full-time employees of the United States will not receive additional compensation but will be reimbursed for travel and other expenses. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct appoints an Executive Director who receives compensation at a specified rate. The Executive Director can appoint additional personnel as needed without following certain regulations. The Executive Director of the Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct can procure personal services of experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the highest level payable under the General Schedule pay rates. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct can request administrative and research services from the Administrative Office of the United States Courts and the Federal Judicial Center on a reimbursable basis. It may also request information and assistance from any department, agency, or independent instrumentality of the Federal Government as needed. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct can request information and assistance from any department, agency, or independent instrumentality of the Federal Government as authorized by law. The Attorney General must submit a report to the Commission within 60 days of the Act's enactment, detailing investigations conducted by the Office of Professional Responsibility of the Department of Justice in the preceding 3 years. The Commission on Federal Prosecutorial Conduct can investigate willful misconduct by Department of Justice employees. The report must be confidential and not interfere with investigations or privacy rights. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report and can receive up to $900,000 in appropriations.
